revision.text:
{{Infobox comedian | name = Cameron Esposito | image = Cameron Esposito by Gage Skidmore.jpg | imagesize =220px | alt = Cameron Esposito speaking into a microphone. She is Caucasian, has an asymmetrical haircut, and is wearing a leather jacket. | caption = Esposito in 2016. | birth_name = Cameron Anne Young Anastasia Esposito | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1981|10|17|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Western Springs, Illinois]], U.S. | children = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Rhea Butcher]]
|2015|2018|reason={{abbr|sep.|separated}}}} | medium = Stand-up, television, radio, internet | active = 2007–present | genre = | subject = | notable_work = | signature = | alma_mater = [[Benet Academy]], [[Boston College]] | website = {{url|http://CameronEsposito.com}} | module = }} '''Cameron Young Esposito''' (born October 17, 1981) is an American comic, actor, and podcaster, known for her show ''[[Take My Wife (2016 TV series)|Take My Wife]]'', as well as her [[stand-up comedy]] and podcast Queery. Esposito substantially focuses on topics surrounding the [[LGBTQ+|LGBTQ]] community, [[feminism]], [[social justice]], and the challenges faced by members of marginalized communities.{{cite news|authorlink=Lindy West|last= West|first= Lindy|date= August 7, 2014|title= Yo, Men, Cameron Esposito Doesn't Want to Have Sex with You Either|url= http://jezebel.com/yo-men-cameron-esposito-doesnt-want-to-have-sex-with-1617178180|publisher= [[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]]|location= |access-date= April 12, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/10/11/354646177/hugs-for-hecklers-cameron-esposito-on-life-as-a-lesbian-comedian|title=Hugs For Hecklers: Cameron Esposito On Life As A Lesbian Comedian|work=[[NPR]]|author=NPR Staff|date=October 11, 2014}} Originally from [[Western Springs, Illinois]], Esposito resides in [[Los Angeles]] with her spouse and fellow comic [[Rhea Butcher]]. == Early life == Born to Brenda and Nick Esposito, Cameron Anne Young Anastasia Esposito was raised in [[Western Springs, Illinois]].Bosch, Sandy Illian (March 13, 2008). "Western Springs native lands comedy nomination". ''The Doings'' (Burr Ridge–Darien–Willowbrook, Illinois).Nekervis, Erin (August 1, 2011). "Chicago Crush of the Month: Cameron Esposito". ''Chicago Sun-Times''. In high school, Esposito swam [[breast stroke]] on the swim team,Considine, Mike (December 5, 1997). "Lake Park places third at Upstate Eight meet: Benet". ''Daily Herald'' (Arlington Heights, Illinois). p. 5. was a member of a community service group called [[Society of Mary (Marianists)|The Marians Society]],Wowchuk, Stefanie (December 27, 1998). "Marians open their hearts, ears at meetings". ''Daily Herald'' (Arlington Heights, Illinois). p. 1. and was a semifinalist for the [[National Merit Scholarship Program]].Wowchuk, Stefanie (November 7, 1999). "Seniors named National Merit Scholars". ''Daily Herald'' (Arlington Heights, Illinois). p. 3. She graduated from [[Benet Academy]] in 2000."Suburban childhood experiences are comedy gold". ''Daily Herald '' (Arlington Heights, Illinois). February 11, 2014. p. 1."Candidates for graduation from Benet Academy". ''Daily Herald'' (Arlington Heights, Illinois). May 26, 2000. p. 7. Esposito studied theology and English at [[Boston College]], intending to become a social worker in Chicago.Borrelli, Christopher (October 10, 2014). "Comedian Cameron Esposito is on a charm offensive". ''TCA Regional News'' (Chicago). While in Boston, she played [[rugby football|rugby]]Ramirez, Kaylie (May 28, 2018). "Boston Calling Day 3 Burns Out with Enigmatic Eminem Set". ''University Wire'' (Carlsbad, New Mexico). and performed in the school's [[improvisation|improv troupe]], My Mother's Fleabag.Zaino, Nick A., III (June 17, 2015). "No slowing down: Young comic Esposito is 'grinding' out a career". ''Boston Globe''. p. G11. Esposito graduated from Boston College in 2004."[http://bcm.bc.edu/headliners Headliners: Week of June 14, 2015]". ''Boston College Magazine''. Boston College. Retrieved May 30, 2018. After returning to Illinois, Esposito took a semester of social work courses at the [[University of Chicago]] when she realized did not want to be a social worker after all. == Early stand-up career == Esposito began her stand-up career in Chicago, performing in various local venues, including as a regular at The Lincoln Lodge from 2007 to 2011.[http://thelincolnlodge.com/alumni/ "Alumni"]. TheLincolnLodge.com. Accessed February 1, 2015. She appeared at a number of comedy festivals, including [[SXSW]], the Moontower, [[Bridgetown Comedy Festival]], and [[SF Sketchfest]]. To supplement her income, she worked with students in [[special education]], as a [[law clerk]] at her father's law firm, and as a [[nanny]].Parikh, Rima (November 1, 2015). "A Q & A with comedian Cameron Esposito". ''University Wire'' (Carlsbad, New Mexico). == 2013–present == In 2013, Esposito made her television debut on ''[[The Late, Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''. Fellow guest [[Jay Leno]] expressed admiration for Esposito, calling her "the future of comedy".Luippold, Ross. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/04/jay-leno-interrupts-cameron-esposito-late-night-debut_n_3867277.html "Jay Leno Interrupts Cameron Esposito's Stand-Up, Calls Gay Female Comic 'The Future{{'"}}]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', September 4, 2013. She has also appeared on ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''Bendix, Trish. [http://www.afterellen.com/tv/224628-watch-now-cameron-esposito-gets-gay-on-conan "Watch Now! Cameron Gets Gay on Conan"]. [[AfterEllen.com]], August 15, 2014. and on ''[[Last Call with Carson Daly]]''. She also voiced "Carroll the Cloud Person" on an episode of [[Cartoon Network]]'s animated show ''[[Adventure Time]]''. The entertainment media website [[Consequence of Sound]] named Esposito its comedian of the year for 2014.Pickett, Leah. [http://consequenceofsound.net/2014/12/comedian-of-the-year-cameron-esposito/ "Comedian of the Year: Cameron Esposito"]. Consequence of Sound, December 8, 2014. In the fall of 2014, Esposito created a series of videos with [[BuzzFeed]] Motion Pictures titled "Ask a Lesbian",Habersburger, Keith. [https://www.buzzfeed.com/keithhabersberger/ask-a-lesbian-with-cameron-esposito#.va9VV4bKdZ "Questions You Wish You Could Ask a Lesbian"]. BuzzFeed.com, October 31, 2014. in which she answers a variety of questions sent in to BuzzFeed staff about lesbianism. The videos also feature Butcher, with whom she has performed comedy previously.Star, Erika. [http://www.afterellen.com/general-news/105780-lez-stand-out-rhea-butcher-and-cameron-esposito "Lez Stand Out: Rhea Butcher and Cameron Esposito"]. AfterEllen.com, February 20, 2013. In addition to touring regularly, Esposito was a regular panelist on ''[[Chelsea Lately]]'' with [[Chelsea Handler]]Fathelbab, Mo. [http://www.theexcomedy.com/why-arent-you-following-cameron-esposito/ "Why Aren't You Following?: Cameron Esposito"]. TheExperiement.com, May 19, 2014. and used to write a regular blog on the website ''[[The A.V. Club]]''.[http://www.avclub.com/search?feature_types=who-in-the-world-is-cameron-esposito "Who in the World Is Cameron Esposito?"] ''TheAVClub.com'' Accessed January 29, 2015. Her comedy album ''Same Sex Symbol'' was released in December 2014 by the independent record label [[Kill Rock Stars]]. Esposito appeared on Comedy Central's ''[[Drunk History]]'' as a storyteller on October 20, 2015. Esposito also co-hosts the stand up comedy podcast "Put Your Hands Together" with Rhea Butcher, which is recorded weekly in front of a live audience at the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in Los Angeles.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ucbtheatre.com/show/3347|title=Put Your Hands Together with Cameron Esposito and Rhea Butcher|website=UCB Theatre|language=en|access-date=2018-02-23}} Esposito is known for her ground-breaking{{Cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2018/06/cameron-esposito-rape-jokes/|title=With “Rape Jokes,” Cameron Esposito Turns the Lowest Form of Comedy Into Something Groundbreaking|last=Walrath|first=Rowan|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en-us}} lesbian content creation, especially hers and Butcher's television show ''[[Take My Wife (2016 TV series)|Take My Wife]]'', which streamed on [[Seeso]] until the service was discontinued in November 2017.{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/theater/ct-ent-cameron-esposito-1012-story.html|title=Cameron Esposito and Rhea Butcher's 'Back to Back' comedy tour feels more urgent with their TV show in limbo|last=Johnson|first=Steve|work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=2018-02-23|language=en-US}} In March 2018, ''Take My Wife'' was picked up by [[iTunes]] and season 2 became available to the public.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/08/watching/what-to-watch-this-weekend.html|title=How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?|last=Lyons|first=Margaret|access-date=2018-03-11|language=en-us}} The show was then acquired by [[Starz]] in April 2018.https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/starz-acquires-take-my-wife-new-deal-1202754084/ Additionally, Esposito's podcast ''Queery'' is an interview-style podcast focusing on contemporary queer luminaries and their life experiences.{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/queery-with-cameron-esposito/id1268343859?mt=2|title=QUEERY with Cameron Esposito by Cameron Esposito on Apple Podcasts|website=Apple Podcasts|language=en|access-date=2018-02-23}} Queery guests have included [[Rhea Butcher]], [[Lena Waithe]], [[Tegan and Sara|Tegan Quin]], [[Tegan and Sara|Sara Quin]], [[Evan Rachel Wood]], [[Jill Soloway]], [[Mary Lambert (singer)|Mary Lambert]], [[Andrea Gibson]], [[Margaret Cho]], [[Alia Shawkat]], [[Roxane Gay]], [[Trixie Mattel]], and [[Lea DeLaria]].http://www.earwolf.com/show/queery/ On June 11, 2018 Esposito released Rape Jokes, an hour long standup special about sexual assault from her perspective as a survivor, on her website.{{Cite news|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/05/cameron-esposito-me-too-rape-jokes-comedy-take-my-wife|title=The #MeToo Movement Has a Place in Comedy: Just Ask Cameron Esposito|last=Robinson|first=Joanna|work=HWD|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.vulture.com/2018/05/cameron-esposito-rapes-jokes-survivors-sexual-assault.html|title=The Comedian Who Is Taking Rape Jokes Back for Survivors|last=Fox|first=Jesse David|work=Vulture|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/rambling-reporter/cameron-esposito-s-rape-jokes-debuts-online-today-1117336|title=Cameron Esposito's 'Rape Jokes' Comedy Act Debuts Online|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/news/cameron-espositos-rape-jokes-special-interview-1202843555/|title=Cameron Esposito on ‘Rape Jokes,’ Her New Comedy Special Tackling Sexual Assault and Consent|last=Framke|first=Caroline|date=2018-06-13|work=Variety|access-date=2018-06-14|language=en-US}} The special was free to stream, but viewers could pay to download a copy and proceeds would benefit [[Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network|RAINN]], the United States' largest anti-sexual violence organization. The special raised over $50k in donations within ten days of its release. == Filmography == ===Film=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Year !! Title !! Label |- | 2010 || ''[https://itunes.apple.com/nz/album/grab-them-aghast/359517807 Grab Them Aghast]'' || Rooftop Comedy Records |- | 2015 || ''[https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/same-sex-symbol/916861411 Same Sex Symbol]'' || Kill Rock Stars |- | 2016 || ''[https://itunes.apple.com/us/movie/cameron-esposito-marriage-material/id1366104635 Marriage Material]'' || Comedy Dynamics |- | 2017 || ''[https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/back-to-back/1314542150 Back to Back]'' || aspecialthing records |- | 2018 || ''[https://cameronesposito.com/rapejokes Rape Jokes]'' || aspecialthing records |} ===Podcasts=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role |- | 2013–present || ''[https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/put-your-hands-together-with-cam-and-rhea/id593136300?mt=2 Put Your Hands Together]'' || Host |- | 2013–2015 || ''[https://itunes.apple.com/tr/podcast/wham-bam-pow-with-cameron-esposito/id1278580624?mt=2 Wham Bam Pow]'' || Host |- | 2013–present || ''[[Comedy Bang! Bang!]]'' || Guest |- | 2014 || ''[[My Brother, My Brother and Me]]'' || Guest |- | 2014–2016 || ''[[How Did This Get Made?]]'' || Guest |- | 2015 || ''[[With Special Guest Lauren Lapkus]]'' || Guest |- | 2016 || “[[Bad with Money with Gaby Dunn]]” || Guest |- | 2017–present || ''[https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/queery-with-cameron-esposito/id1268343859?mt=2 Queery]'' || Host |- | 2017 || ''Nancy'' || Guest |- | 2017 || ''Homophilia'' || Guest |} ===Online=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Title !! Role !! Notes |- | 2018 || ''[[Good Mythical Morning]]'' || Guest || |} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == *{{official website|http://cameronesposito.com}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Esposito, Cameron}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:21st-century American actresses]] [[Category:21st-century American comedians]] [[Category:American podcasters]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:American television actresses]] [[Category:American women comedians]] [[Category:Boston College alumni]] [[Category:Feminist comedians]] [[Category:Lesbian actresses]] [[Category:LGBT comedians]] [[Category:LGBT entertainers from the United States]] [[Category:LGBT people from Illinois]] [[Category:Living people]]
